Award.AwardTitle: NUE: The Freshman Experience and Nanotechnology Solutions to Engineering Grand Challenges

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this NUE project, The Fresman Experience and Nanotechnology Solutions to Engineering Grand Challenges, at Auburn University (AU), under the direction of Dr. Virginia Davis, is to develop six education modules that utilize Engineering Grand Challenges as a framework for teaching nanotechnology to freshmen engineering students. The goals of these modules will be to 1) increase nanotechnology awareness and understanding as part of achieving ABET student outcomes 2) to familiarize students with the current grand challenges in engineering and potential nanotechnology enabled solutions, and 3) to increase student understanding of the importance of grand challenges and nanotechnology to the engineering profession.

A well trained diverse pool of professional engineers is critical for the continued advancement of society. Nanotechnology will be a critical factor in this advancement and engineers will be increasingly expected to be knowledgeable in this field. Within the Auburn University's College of Engineering (AU), the modules will be disseminated through the ENGR 1110 courses offered by each department, a minority summer bridge program (AEP), and six living learning communities (including two focused on underrepresented groups). Beyond AU dissemination will occur through NanoHub, the National Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Education Digital Library (NSDL), YouTube, and presentations and peer reviewed publications. It is expected that these modules will not only result in knowledge gains, but increase student engagement and retention. This will enhance the STEM diversity. AU is ranked 7th in terms of the number of engineering degrees awarded to African American students and has a growing number of Hispanic students. In addition, module components may be used in the PIs ongoing outreach and diversity activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of a skilled (Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics) STEM workforce is critical to the US economy and the wellbeing of its citizens. Engineers in particular are desperately needed to fill key positions in the labor pool. However, there is often a misunderstanding of what engineers do for humanity. The National Academy of Engineering’s Engineering Grand Challenges is a list of 14 engineering-related challenges that, if solved, would have a profound societal impact. Other STEM areas also have well know grand challenges such as the “Millennium Prize” problems for mathematics and the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council list of “Physics Grand Challenges.” However, the NAE list stands out in that the challenges listed are directly related to an issue society faces, such as providing access to clean water. The Engineering Grand Challenges build on the NAE’s efforts to improve the public’s understanding of engineering and portray it as an important and exciting profession that has profound impacts on society.

There have been a large number of efforts to improve both formal and informal K-12 nanotechnology education. Due largely to these efforts there is a large body of high quality material for teaching student in the K-12 grade about nanotechnology. However, there has not been a similar effort to incorporate nanotechnology education in the freshman engineering courses. As a new and exciting area of research there are ample opportunities for study at the graduate level. However, there are few undergraduate courses that teach nanotechnology concepts. A result most engineering freshman, a growing number of whom have developed a high degree of interest in the potential of nanotechnology, must wait until graduate school or, if they are lucky, senior level elective classes to obtain any further nanotechnology education. In addition, nanotechnology’s impact is predicted to be comparable to the invention of the automobile, and nanotechnology is already a part of everyday life (e.g. sporting goods, deodorants, paints, and advanced electronics). Therefore, all engineers, not just a few specialists, will need to be nanotechnology literate to perform their jobs.

The objective of this work was to develop education modules that utilize Engineering Grand Challenges as a framework for teaching nanotechnology to freshmen engineering students. The goals of these modules were to 1) increase nanotechnology awareness and understanding 2) to familiarize students with the current grand challenges in engineering and potential nanotechnology enabled solutions, and 3) to increase student understanding of the importance of grand challenges and nanotechnology to the engineering profession. Through the grant the PIs were able to develop 4 complete modules and reach over 1,500 students both through presentations in the “Introduction to Engineering” courses at Auburn University and by presentation of portions of the modules at several summer camps for advanced high school students. The modules included various activities and lab work. In the module based on the grand challenge “Reverse Engineer the Brain” students utilized probes of differing sizes, down to microscale, to locate objects buried in model brains, see figure. In the module based on “Make Solar Energy Economical” students built and explored performance of a dye sensitized solar cell, see figure. In the module based on “Provide access to clean water” students used several filtration systems, including filters impregnated with nanoscale silver to clean contaminated water. As part of the module based on the challenge “Restore and improve urban infrastructure” students explored how nanotechnology can be used to make stronger materials, prepare self-cleaning surfaces, and how nature uses nanotechnology to produce robust materials.
